I dont have much experience but our mentors say oneshape is better bc of being capable of editing the same project and being overall more basic and easy to learn.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T20:26:55.578Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":696,"readers_count":695,"score":159.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Kemal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72139,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mechanic"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/2","custom_user_title":"Mechanic","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558596,"name":"Nathan","username":"NathanLaraway","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanlaraway/{size}/261646_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T20:35:08.183Z","cooked":"

I’ve worked with both, and I definitely think Onshape is the better program, especially if you’re new to CAD. The only reason to stick with SolidWorks is if you’re already comfortable with it, but even then, I think switching to Onshape is worth it.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T20:41:47.840Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":603,"readers_count":602,"score":400.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Anthony Ung","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":61769,"username":"Soren_1","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/soren_1/{size}/262420_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":17}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66446,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/5","custom_user_title":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":14},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":21,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558606,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T20:48:42.687Z","cooked":"

I’ve been running Solidworks for almost a decade now.
It’s a lot more powerful than Onshape but a lot of the features in Solidworks (for example, many teams don’t use simulation) just aren’t needed for FRC use.
Solidworks however is used far more in the industry.
On a more personal note, I hate the way Onshape works, and I also have not had reliable internet access for the nearly 10 years I’ve been running solidworks, thank you AT&T, so YMMV

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T20:48:42.687Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":582,"readers_count":581,"score":196.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/6","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558617,"name":"Harrison Drake","username":"HDrake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hdrake/{size}/5033_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T20:57:57.276Z","cooked":"

We swapped in 2021 to Onshape from Solidworks and 100% will not go back (pending a reversal on their EDU support).

The real benefit is student accessibility. Pretty much anything from a school issued iPad or random family laptop up to full blown CAD workstations can access our robot CAD. Solidworks requirements to properly load a robot master model are just not in reach for most people/families.

We have seen an explosion in student prototyping and robot design involvement since the swap. Basically went from 80% mentors/20% students to a complete swap of today’s 80% students/20% mentors. Easiest way to end up with a mentor built bot is use a CAD system pretty much only the mentors can actually run.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T20:57:57.276Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":560,"readers_count":559,"score":582.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Harrison Drake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":29}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Technical Mentor, WSRP"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/7","custom_user_title":"Lead Technical Mentor, WSRP","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":27},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":29,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560040,"name":"Joe Johnson","username":"Joe_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_johnson/{size}/156076_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T01:47:14.342Z","cooked":"

So true. That fact that any old laptop (the one I have used for a year now cost me literally $150) can run Onshape and have the latest version of Onshape without having to jump through any hoops to get runing is a HUGE reduction in friction that I think has helped get many more students driving CAD.

Another great advantage is that every person on the CAD team is always be looking at the latest CAD and isn’t blocked by having to check in/ check out files, download the latest versions, resolved possible conflicts, risk over writing their work, etc. It is another barrier to driving CAD that is vastly reduced by using Onshape.

I know Onshape is far from perfect and isn’t right for every application but for a FIRST Team, I think it is the best CAD tool out there (FWIW, I have professionally used over a half dozen CAD packages - including NX, Creo, SW, and Onshape.)

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T01:47:14.342Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":464,"readers_count":463,"score":307.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Joe Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":14782,"username":"HDrake","name":"Harrison Drake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hdrake/{size}/5033_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":14}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":6,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":13},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560068,"name":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","username":"RicDV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ricdv/{size}/188502_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T02:11:42.462Z","cooked":"

While I am not a CAD guy…I have to look at cost as a consideration. Free (FRC password) to whatever level of Solidworks you buy.

Now, some schools have CAD and they MAY use Solidworks for classes…and it makes sense to use it for robotics. In our case…we have to use what we can on the cheap. For us, MKCAD is a bonus to use. I am not sure if Solidworks has a version of it.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T02:11:42.462Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":419,"readers_count":418,"score":98.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5503"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/9","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5503","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560070,"name":"","username":"pigrammer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pigrammer/{size}/234083_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T02:14:06.658Z","cooked":"
Joe_Johnson:

Another great advantage is that every person on the CAD team is always be looking at the latest CAD and isn’t blocked by having to check in/ check out files, download the latest versions, resolved possible conflicts, risk over writing their work, etc. It is another barrier to driving CAD that is vastly reduced by using Onshape.

Not just the CAD team, it’s really useful for me as a programmer to be able to look at the latest version of the CAD, and for the people machining parts to just go to cad.onshape.com and see what they need to do.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T02:14:06.658Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":147.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://cad.onshape.com","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Onshape","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64857,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"246 Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/10","custom_user_title":"246 Software Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560077,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T02:19:02.337Z","cooked":"
RicDV:

whatever level of Solidworks you buy

Last I checked, SW also gave FRC discounts, I want to say free but I could be wrong on that.

In a direct head-to-head, right now I’d pick Onshape, mainly for the file-sharing and ability to work wherever on whatever device.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T02:19:02.337Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":381,"readers_count":380,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/11","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560079,"name":"","username":"pigrammer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pigrammer/{size}/234083_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T02:22:37.421Z","cooked":"

Last I checked, SW also gave FRC discounts, I want to say free but I could be wrong on that.

Indeed free.

https://www.solidworks.com/product/students/free-solidworks-first-robotics-teams

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T02:22:37.421Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":378,"readers_count":377,"score":135.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.solidworks.com/product/students/free-solidworks-first-robotics-teams","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Free SOLIDWORKS for FIRST® Teams | SOLIDWORKS","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64857,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"246 Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/12","custom_user_title":"246 Software Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560101,"name":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","username":"RicDV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ricdv/{size}/188502_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T02:35:59.470Z","cooked":"

In fairness…I will have to check it out…to make an informed decision for the team.

That said…our CAD people are doing fairly well with Onshape so far…despite learning it after school.

for newcomers to CAD and design, along with collaboration i suggest onshape. the resources for frc in onshape are limitless and the collaboration features are peak. also mk cad

personally i prefer solidworks and beyond that siemens nx due to the advanced features and combination of cad and cam. def more advanced but if you plan to work in an industry that utilizes cad, solidworks is a must. both are great!

both have free student editions as well, tho the solidworks is specific to frc and comes in the kit of parts

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T02:46:43.726Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":67.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5503"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/16","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5503","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560127,"name":"Chris_Elston","username":"Chris_Elston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_elston/{size}/256883_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T03:01:16.932Z","cooked":"
Yazwq:

Which do you think is more useful for the build?

Here is my personal opinion.

We started out with a traditional CAD system. AutoDesk Inventor. The high school taught it, it seemed to make sense to use it, we had to have high end computers to run it and everyone had to use the CAD system in person.

Then covid came. We switched to a WEB BASED CAD system, and it just made sense for us to switch to AutoDesk Fusion. This was an AWESOME MOVE! Because now we could be at home as a CAD team, sharing our drawings in the cloud and we could use our own computers at home, the library computer, a laptop, my work computer, ANYTHING to open Fusion so long as we downloaded the Fusion installer. We also like that it’s easy to send STEP files to our 3D printer through Fusion. I really liked Fusion personally still today.

By industry standard skills, like CAD skills the kids can use when they leave your team, I think a standard CAD tool like Solidworks, Inventor, Fusion is more in line with what an engineering shop would use. I have yet to run into an engineering machine house that uses OnShape…

HOWEVER…The VALUE I see with Onshape is TIME…It took us probably twice as long to draw something in a standard CAD PACKAGE, because the FRC community has not really embraced all the CAD shortcuts that OnShape has. MKCAD is a huge time saver! All of the FEATURE SCRIPTS are a HUGE TIME SAVER! I mean to change a tube profile, or lighten holes in plates are just MAGIC, draw belts, auto part numbers, etc…other CAD programs you have to manually draw all that, build your own library which gets outdated pretty quick and it equals TIME. A vendor releases a part at midnight, and by 8am the next morning, it shows up in MKCAD like magic…I dunno who does that, but it’s magic.

I would say comfortably, that OnShape saved us 50% of the hours to draw an FRC robot than a standard CAD package just based on the community support and tools it has. And you don’t need to install anything, update anything like Fusion every day, and it’s all web based so anyone can CAD from home or anywhere with a web browser so long as you have GOOD INTERNET is key…

But is OnShape good for real life after the kids go to college? I personally have not seen it yet talking to a lot of engineers who design automation equipment out there in the world.

OnShape is different if you are use to a standard CAD software to me at least it is. I picked up Fusion fast, I am still struggling with OnShape’s work flow to keep up with the kids, for some reason the kids pick it up quick… but I still value the time it saves which is really important to use to get the CAD released as soon as possible in most cases. Another important note, I am not the CAD mentor, but I picked up CAD to help out with concepts mostly. These are all just my personal opinions.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T03:01:16.932Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":123.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495810,"topic_slug":"solidworks-vs-onshape","display_username":"Chris_Elston","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3040,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-vs-onshape/495810/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560144,"name":"Harrison Drake","username":"HDrake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hdrake/{size}/5033_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T03:27:57.413Z","cooked":"
Chris_Elston:

But is OnShape good for real life after the kids go to college? I personally have not seen it yet talking to a lot of engineers who design automation equipment out there in the world.

Legacy data is the largest hurdle for any company looking to switch.

And why Solidworks can get away with their level of……… “reliability” and still be #1 by market share.

Onshape providing free seats to EDU accounts is them investing in market share for the future.
